references: McClelland, B. R. and P. T. McClelland. 2000. Red-naped sapsucker nest trees in northern Rocky Mountain old-growth forest. Wilson Bulletin, 112(1): 44-50.

Cooper, S.J. 2000. Seasonal energetics of Mountain Chickadee and Juniper Titmouse Condor 103:361-369.

Ligon, J.S. 1961. New Mexico birds and where to find them. The University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque.
Garrett, K. and J. Dunn. 1981. Birds of southern California: status and distribution. Los Angeles Audubon Soc. Los Angeles, CA.
Airola, D.A., and R.H. Barrett. 1985. Foraging and habitat relationships of insect-gleaning birds in a Sierra Nevada mixed-conifer forest. Condor 87:205-216.

mixed-coniferous forest. Condor 80:431-441.

grazed and ungrazed pinyon-juniper woodlands. Journal of Wildlife Management. 62(2):474-484

Colorado Division of Wildlife, Publishers.

Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.
Laudenslayer, W. E, and R. P. Balda. 1976. Breeding bird use of a pinyon-juniper-ponderosa ecotone. Auk 93:571-586.
Martin, S. G. and K. A. Martin. 1996. Hybridization between a Mountain Chickadee and Black-capped Chickadee in Colorado. Colo. Field Ornithol. J. 30:60-65.
Alcorn, J. R. 1988. The birds of Nevada. Fairview West Publishing, Fallon, NV.

Mccallum, D. Archibald, Ralph Grundel and Donald L. Dahlsten. 1999. Mountain Chickadee (Poecile gambeli), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/453.
O’Meara, T.E., J.B. Haufler, L.H. Stelter, and J.G. Nagy. 1981. Nongame wildlife responses to chaining of pinyon-juniper woodlands. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 45(2):381-389.
Douglas, D.C., J.T. Ratti, R.A. Black, and J.R. Allredge. 1992. Avian habitat associations in riparian zones of Idaho's Centennial Mountains. Wilson Bulletin 104(3):485-500.
Hill, B. G., and M. R. Lein. 1989. Territory overlap and habitat use of sympatric chickadees. Auk 106:259-268.
Phillips, A., J. Marshall, and G. Monson. 1964. The Birds of Arizona. The University of Arizona Press, Tucson, AZ.
Rosenberg, K. V., R.D. Ohmart, W.C. Hunter, and B.W. Anderson. 1991. Birds of the lower Colorado River Valley University of Arizona Press, Tucson.
Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
In areas of sparse population, may hybridize with Black-capped Chickadee (Poecile atricapillus) (McCallum et al. 1999).  Year-round resident of montane coniferous forests of western North America, primarily in areas dominated by pine, spruce, fir, and pinyon-juniper (McCallum et al. 1999).  Also in mixed coniferous-deciduous forests and riparian zones (McCallum et al. 1999).  Generally inhabit ponderosa pine forests in Arizona (Laudenslayer and Balda 1976).  Can be found in Colorado in pinyon-juniper woodlands, mainly pinyon pine and Utah juniper, with shrub species of big sagebrush (Artemisia tridentata), Utah serviceberry (Amelanchier utahensis), true mountain mahogany (Cercocarpus montanus), rubber rabbitbrush (Chrysothamnus nauseosus) and mountain snowberry (Symphoricarpos oreophilus) (O'Meara et al. 1981). In the centennial mountains of Idaho, this species can be found in the summer at elevations ranging from 1860-1940 m, with major vegetation including lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta), Engelmann spruce (Picea engelmannii), Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), quaking aspen (Populus tremuloides) and willows (Douglas et al. 1992).  In Utah can be found in areas of mixed conifers and quaking aspen (Populus tremuloides) at elevations of 2200 m (Cooper 2000).  Found in northern Arizona at breeding time in Ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa)  communities and Ponderosa pine-Gambel oak (Quercus gambelii) communities, with an herbaceous understory of Arizona fescue (Festuca arizonica) and blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis) (Rosenstock 1998).  Found as a resident in Colfax County, New Mexico in grazed and ungrazed rangeland consisting of blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis), pinyon pine (Pinus edulis), and one-seed juniper (Juniperus monosperma) (Goguen and Mathews 1998).  Found in mixed-coniferous forests in the White Mountains of Arizona (Franzreb and Ohmart 1978).  This species can be found nesting in Montana in paper birch (Betula papyrifera) in cavities excavated by red-naped sapsuckers (McClelland and McClelland 2000).  In Colorado, this species mainly lives in mountain conifer forests (Kingery 1998).  Highest densities in Colorado were old growth spruce/fir, lodgepole pine, and ponderosa pine forests; although this species occurred extensively in pinyon-juniper, it did not breed there often (Kingery 1998).  In Arizona, this species is a common resident in pine and spruce-fir forests; this is one of the most conspicuous birds in the winter forests of northern Arizona (Phillips et al. 1964).  A casual fall and winter visitor in the lower Colorado River Valley, this species has been documented in cottonwood-willow riparian woodland (Rosenberg et al. 1991).  This species is resident in most of the mountain ranges statewide.  This species is one of the most widespread of the chickadees inhabiting New Mexico (Ligon 1961).  In New Mexico in summer it ranges from 2,287 m to near timberline; nests from 2,134 to 3,659 m (Ligon 1961). Occurs in winter as low as 1,524 m at Shiprock (Ligon 1961). In Colorado, breeds between 1,982-3,659 m (Kingery 1998). Has been recorded between 1,677-2,927 m in Nevada (Alcorn 1988).
In n. Arizona, Mountain Chickadee used piñon pines disproportionately (Laudenslayer and Balda 1976); in ne. California, preferred white fir (Abies concolor) as foraging substrate in forest composed of white fir, ponderosa pine, incense cedar, and western juniper (J. occidentalis; Grundel 1984). In w. Sierra Nevada mixed-conifer forest, spent majority of time foraging in white fir, but foraging varied by season and spent more time on California black oak (Quercus kelloggii) during fall (Sep–Oct), on incense cedar during winter (Nov–Feb), and on sugar pine (Pinus lambertiana) in late summer (Jul–Aug; L. A. Brennan, M. L. Morrison, and DLD unpubl.)(quoted directly from Mccallum et al. 1999).
In California, this species frequents coniferous forests, especially ponderosa, Jeffrey, lodgepole, and eastside pine, as well as red fir and mixed conifer habitats (quoted directly from Green et al. taken from Zeiner et al. 1990).  

Northwest:
Mainly year-round resident of montane coniferous forests of w. North America, primarily in areas dominated by pine, spruce-fir (Picea-Abies), and piñon-juniper (Pinus-Juniperus; Dixon 1961, Am. Ornithol. Union 1983). Occurs in mixed coniferous-deciduous forests and riparian zones, where it uses conifers more than expected by chance (e.g., Airola and Bennett 1985, Douglas et al. 1992, L. A. Brennan, M. L. Morrison, and DLD unpubl.)(quoted directly from Mccallum et al. 1999). 



Winter:
Similar to breeding habitat, since some individuals remain on breeding territories and others relocate within breeding habitat. Also includes nonbreeding habitat, mostly broadleaf vegetation (e.g., cottonwoods) in human plantings (Martin and Martin 1996) and riparian areas below breeding elevations (quoted directly from Mccallum et al. 1999).
In California during winter, this mountain chickadees may move downslope to riparian and hardwood habitats. In the south, regularly moves downslope to foothills, irregularly to coast and desert regions. In the north, downslope movement occasionally extends to the humid outer coastal ranges (Grinnell and Miller 1944, McCaskie et al. 1979, Garrett and Dunn 1981)(quoted directly from Green et al. taken from Zeiner et al. 1990).
